title: `run` permission dance issue
body:
Usecase: I wanted to `singularity build` an image inside `datalad run`. The build itself needs to run as root, but ideally datalad itself would not need to. Here is my attempt:

```
% datalad run -d . --input Singularity --output container.simg -m "Build Singularity image from Docker" \
    sudo singularity build {outputs} {inputs}
```

which leads to:

```
[INFO   ] == Command exit (modification check follows) ===== 
Total:   0%|                                                                | 0.00/4.55G [00:00<?, ?B/s][WARNING] Running add resulted in stderr output:   container.simg: setFileMode: permission denied (Operation not permitted)
git-annex: add: 1 failed
 
Total:   0%|                                                                | 0.00/4.55G [00:00<?, ?B/s][WARNING] Running add resulted in stderr output:   container.simg: setFileMode: permission denied (Operation not permitted)
git-annex: add: 1 failed
 
File(s) unknown to git
```

which is not unexpected:

```
% ll
total 4.3G
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 4.3G Jul  1 09:21 container.simg*
-rw-rw-r-- 1 mih  mih    86 Jul  1 09:04 Singularity
```

I wonder what you guys think would be a better approach. Running the entire command through `sudo` will probably mess up permissions in the object store(s), but most importantly DataLad will have no record that this particular command needs god-mode.
